column4: OK, this is my idiotic question for the day: Is there a way to get the grub bootloader to open the CD-ROM drive?
Or, I guess, some way to open a CD-ROM drive on a non-bootable computer where there's no button on the front to open it?
plug the drive in another machine?
or if you dont care about the drive, screwdriver :)
you dont have to boot to open the CD, you can do that any time power is on
or if there is no open button, plug it into another pc :)
you could try booting a usb stick instead
or for real hacker cred, theres network booting with tftpd :)
tftpd ? no risks, your network card has to support it though
most modern cards do
you need a second linux box to run tftpd and dhcp on
tftpd has been arround for dozen years plus, should be in all distributions as a package
otherwise, ftp://www.kernel.org/pub/software/network/tftp/

you have to setup dhcp and tftpd though, dhcp you put the mac address of the box and the information about which tftpd server, which boot files to grab from it, and then the tftpd server has to be setup to server those files
no, on the other computer
then when your broken pc boots (you might need to go into bios to enable network booting) it will ask dhcp for an ip address, and dhcp will also tell it which tftpd server to get boot files from
if you dont get a network boot screen that flashes for a second on the machine before booting, go into bios and make sure network boot is in there somewhere
it might call it PXE boot or something
network boot? no live cd, although you do have to have some sort of boot image
a small livecd would probably work
it has to fit in memory of the other machine
most of them have a pinhole you can push a paperclip into
make sure its not the LED though :)
